BUZZWORD OF THE WEEK comp-os-ability:

a principle for building systems that lets developers mix and match modular components. useful for creating flexible, scalable tech stacks.

enables quick adaptation to changing needs. found in software, cloud, and even business strategy.

modularity ensures pieces work together seamlessly. like building a LEGO set that powers websites, apps, or entire networks.

Check out more of our favorite buzzwords here.

Strong Convictions, Loosely Held: El Prof‚Äôs DeFi Predictions for 2025

What‚Äôs in a prediction that makes it worthwhile? Is it predicting tomorrow‚Äôs closing Bitcoin price? Maybe. Surely the finance people who read this say definitely, but the information arbitrage gap is closing so fast these days that competing algorithms predicting the price create a new chaos unto themselves.

My philosophy when it comes to predicting trends and the future is ‚Äústrong convictions, loosely held.‚Äù I‚Äôm easily swayed by compelling new data. Anyone who wants to consider themselves rational has to be ‚Äî even, especially when it conflicts with our priors, or our ego. (The latter of which is usually the problem when it comes to making accurate predictions in the first place.)

Case in point: Solana is hovering around $180. I said it wouldn‚Äôt go below $200. Just goes to show you should not take any advice on financial positioning from me. A qualified investment advisor can coach you on when to buy it. I can just tell you if it‚Äôs building towards a real market or not. So, with those obligatory risk disclosures aside, here‚Äôs my wildest speculations for what 2025 could have in store.

The obvious potential catalyst is Trump‚Äôs looming inauguration. (For more on that, read to the end.) With a leader in charge of the nation‚Äôs ego ‚Äî and as obviously sensitive of his own ‚Äî you bet your ass leading innovation in the fields of security, cryptography, distributed ledgers and filestore systems, peer2peer protocols, and quantum computing are going to be prioritized over anything else. Why? These are the technologies required to operate as sovereign individuals in an increasingly unified and artificially intelligent world, and that‚Äôs good for business.

To that end, here are my official predictions for 2025:

Q1

Community-managed AI agents with personalities. (s/o @newgleen.eth for inspo on this one.) In other words, personified tokens used to control the weights of different interests that can be held, governed, and stored on a chain. Now that these LLM agent systems have been connected to social media accounts and the like, there are channels for investors to interact with these ‚Äúcharacters‚Äù and watch them come to life. 

Crypto payments to creators led by X, followed by Meta, Reddit, and TikTok (if it survives the next couple weeks). The normalization of crypto as social media compensation could in turn stoke the development of utility tokens across all major platforms to reward quality content production programmatically. X already started creator payouts and has been teasing wanting to have a wallet app for years. This one doesn‚Äôt seem too far-fetched, or far off.

Q2

A social credit scoring system. Elon Musk is already flirting with this one on the app formerly known as Twitter, although the logical extreme of leveraging ZK proofs for identity management is more likely to come from Black Mirror rejects like Sam Altman‚Äôs Worldcoin project. Let‚Äôs grok about that.

Meta will push their AI agents even further to promote products and engage with its real users. Given the success of the meta narrative of AI agents in general, it‚Äôs only a matter of time until the gap is bridged. Maybe it will finally land on a genuinely cool product in the process. I‚Äôm thinking one-click AI image generation with the finalized outputs minted to chain as NFTs? Feel free to steal this idea, Zuck. I know you‚Äôre no stranger to that.

Q3

Tokenized brand loyalty programs. Your contact information, the ability to communicate with you, and some basic information about your demographics are worth $10 to $100s per year to brands. That‚Äôs how much their advertising calculations tell them their customer retention costs, on a unit economics basis. Imagine capturing a share of that value from the hundreds to thousands of brands for which you‚Äôre a potential consumer. The ability to reward your social behavior, which services their marketing and promotion aims, is a more efficient deployment of that capital. With two consistent years of hype behind the web3 space again, loyalty-oriented platforms could emerge to service the major brands interested in the space again.

First major learn-to-earn platform. On-chain game mechanics are still too slow for the quality gameplay expected of the latest systems. But in pursuit of those game mechanics, retro style games will enable the creation of learning management systems that can leverage the game mechanics to offer a learn-to-earn platform, where a course of information with quizzes can be planned and the completion of levels will be rewarded with tokens. I expect companies to be early adopters, creating novel structures for incentivizing workforce development.

Q4

Personal finance agents. We‚Äôve already seen some mainstream use cases for agentic management of finances. Bots in web3 are nothing new, but many are a group pot that share and distribute risk. I think the next evolution will be to have a chatbot interface powered by an LLM and your personal data, aimed at helping you build a more aligned financial portfolio over time. (One without the misaligned incentives of traditional financial agents.) With rumors of a tokenized stock exchange in Texas, it‚Äôs only a matter of time. What should I buy schwabot?

Digital ID wallets will emerge as a public utility ‚Äî like the one we are building here at playhaus.  The data that represents you digitally is valuable to systems like AI. ‚ÄúDID wallets‚Äù will allow you to capture that value through chain mechanics that designate you as the originator of the data, not the platform you executed the transaction on, and that will make all the difference. And it‚Äôs all built on the back of our buzzword of the week: composability.

‚ÄîEl Prof

SPONSORED BY 1440 MEDIA Daily News for Curious Minds

Be the smartest person in the room by reading 1440! Dive into 1440, where 4 million Americans find their daily, fact-based news fix. We navigate through 100+ sources to deliver a comprehensive roundup from every corner of the internet ‚Äì politics, global events, business, and culture, all in a quick, 5-minute newsletter. It‚Äôs completely free and devoid of bias or political influence, ensuring you get the facts straight. Subscribe to 1440 today.

Sign up now!

  How Long Can the Trump Bump Last?

The crypto sphere has been celebrating the 2024 U.S. election for the past month, with Bitcoin breaching $100,000 and peaking above $106,000 in December. But at the time of writing, it has dropped back down to just above $93,500, and Solana, as the venerable El Prof mentioned, is below its peak as well.

Has the Trump rally hit its ceiling before inauguration day?

Maybe not. But in the spirit of predictions, I‚Äôd argue it‚Äôs a safe bet that the major tokens won‚Äôt regain their recent highs on hype alone. Much of the rally has been predicated on what traders assume President-elect Donald Trump will do upon his return to the White House in 2025. His campaign has made clear intentions to turn the United States into the ‚Äúcrypto capital of the planet.‚Äù But with said return right around the corner, any future catalysts are less likely to be based on intentions than on actions.

To be sure, Trump‚Äôs earliest actions do suggest an intent to follow through on that campaign promise. Under the Biden administration, outgoing SEC Chairman Gary Gensler‚Äôs aggressive regulatory stance caused ripples across the crypto community. Trump, in contrast, has tapped Paul Atkins, a former SEC commissioner and known crypto advocate, to lead the charge at the SEC. Atkins‚Äô support for cryptocurrencies could lead to looser regulations and a more welcoming environment for digital assets, at least in the early days of Trump‚Äôs second term.

Trump has also taken steps to fill key positions with figures who also heavily invested in the success of the crypto sector ‚Äî quite literally. He appointed David Sacks, a venture capitalist with ties to both the crypto and AI industries, as a ‚Äúcrypto czar.‚Äù However, the rush to embrace digital assets without significant oversight comes with its own set of challenges. Critics, including financial expert Carol Alexander, warn that relaxing regulations could lead to greater market manipulation by professional traders at the expense of average investors. These concerns are valid, especially given the chaotic and speculative nature of meme coins and other cryptocurrencies that could benefit from looser rules.

Then of course there‚Äôs Trump‚Äôs suggestion of a U.S. ‚Äústrategic national bitcoin stockpile‚Äù ‚Äî a proposal that the U.S. government begin actively purchasing bitcoin to build a reserve, leveraging seized assets from criminal investigations. Whether this comes to pass, or is viewed as a positive development by the crypto space, remain up in the air. A bitcoin reserve doesn‚Äôt exactly smack of MAGA-world priority, and even if it does materialize, it would seem to us to be a decisive blow against the democratization and decentralization of digital assets. Of course, crypto degens aren‚Äôt well-known for their rational, in-depth analysis. So such a move could still prove to be a short-term catalyst. If nothing else, it might incite some buying activity as Bitcoin maxis hurry to shore up their holdings, with the G-Men throwing their Fed-oras in the ring.

Another stumbling block could be the ample crypto-related conflicts of interest in Trump World. Eric Trump, for example, is reportedly linked to the launch of World Liberty Financial, a new crypto company. While Trump Jr. is not directly part of his father‚Äôs administration, his involvement in this space raises eyebrows, especially when paired with Trump‚Äôs ongoing relationships with major international players, including those from Saudi Arabia and the UAE. Then again, DeFi enthusiasts have shown a persistent willingness to overlook obvious corruption in the quest for quick gains, and there‚Äôs no reason to believe that will change on a federal scale.

In other words, there are plenty of reasons to remain both optimistic ‚Äî and cautious ‚Äî for the trajectory of crypto over the next four years. When the future of a technology hinges on the rationality (or lack thereof) of degenerate gamblers and our Reality Show Host in Chief, it will probably pay to stay on your toes.

‚ÄîMuhammed

GN, Gary

It‚Äôs official ‚Äî Gary Gensler, head of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), is stepping down on January 20th. When facing surefire execution, some czars stand on business, and some flee to Siberia. Word on the street is President-elect Donald Trump is eyeing George W. Bush‚Äôs SEC appointee, Paul Atkins, as a replacement.

The market seems to be taking the news well. (See ‚ÄúMoney Money Money‚Äù above.) And why shouldn‚Äôt it? The legacy of Gensler‚Äôs time at the SEC will be one of chasing and destroying value and innovation on American soil, and soiling his previous reputation as an advocate for the space. The FTX collapse occurred under his watchful eye ‚Äî and with the wink and the nod of every politician that put him in that position, who siphoned cash from the crypto cow during the last cycle, while sullying the name of the industry in the wreckage.

The Trump administration, meanwhile, is likely to be anti-CBDC, but may well support centrally-issued stablecoins, which are de facto the same thing. We could also see the federal government push cryptographic technology as a solution for voter verification. If we do down a path of centrally-authorized digital IDs ‚Äî essentially social security numbers for the 21st century and beyond ‚Äî I‚Äôd argue for a free market of these ID providers. Couple their issuance with the underlying management of the security of the assets themselves, so as to make the technology accessible to the everyday users that need to leverage it, without a fear of financial censorship or hacking/theft of value.

In the post-Gensler world, I expect to see consumer-oriented projects that bring retail users into the space ‚Äî particularly those beyond the pump-and-dump memecoin platforms ‚Äî will be granted some prime real estate to experiment and build the ‚Äúsolution-scape‚Äù.

I‚Äôm hoping that projects like content sharing and publishing platform LBRY ‚Äî formerly heavily litigated by the Gensler-era SEC ‚Äî are given more room to run. Or, perhaps, new technologies spring up to continue down the trail they blazed. My yearning for utility in the space will only continue to grow louder, because retail won‚Äôt buy our bags without it.

May 2025 be the year of delusional vibes, McDoodles cups for all, all-time highs for utilitarian tokens, a resurgence of non-PFP NFT projects, and the death of the term DAO.

There is much to give thanks for. Now let‚Äôs go smash some tryptophan.

‚ÄîEl Prof

16:20 • 19 days ago

Herond Browser

What is a Validator? A Guide to Proof of Stake

What is a Validator? If you‚Äôve ever wondered about the role of validators in blockchain networks, you‚Äôre not alone. Validators are the backbone of Proof of Stake (PoS) systems, ensuring security, consensus, and reliability. They verify transactions, propose blocks, and uphold the network‚Äôs rules. As the blockchain ecosystem evolves, understanding validators is key to appreciating [‚Ä¶] The post Wh

What is a Validator? If you‚Äôve ever wondered about the role of validators in blockchain networks, you‚Äôre not alone. Validators are the backbone of Proof of Stake (PoS) systems, ensuring security, consensus, and reliability. They verify transactions, propose blocks, and uphold the network‚Äôs rules. As the blockchain ecosystem evolves, understanding validators is key to appreciating how decentralized systems function efficiently and sustainably.

Learn more: What is a Blockchain Explorer and How Does It Work?

What is a validator? 

A validator is a crucial participant in blockchain networks, responsible for verifying transactions, maintaining consensus, and ensuring the network‚Äôs security. In Proof of Stake (PoS) systems, validators are chosen based on the tokens they stake as collateral. The more they stake, the higher their chances of validating new blocks.

Validators verify transactions, propose new blocks, and uphold the network‚Äôs rules. They are rewarded for honest actions but risk losing their staked tokens if they act maliciously. This system ensures network security and fairness.

Validators play a vital role in maintaining the decentralization, security, and reliability of blockchain networks, making them essential to the system‚Äôs success.

Learn more: Exploring Web3 Browsers: Secure Ways to Access the Decentralized Web

What does being a validator mean?

Being a validator means becoming a cornerstone of a blockchain network, tasked with upholding its security, efficiency, and trustworthiness. Validators are essential for ensuring the smooth operation of decentralized systems. Here‚Äôs what the role involves:

Verifying Transactions: Validators check that each transaction meets the network‚Äôs rules, such as having valid signatures, sufficient account balances, and no double-spending. For instance, Ethereum 2.0 requires validators to process thousands of transactions daily to keep the network functional.
Validating Blocks: They review and approve new blocks by verifying the transactions within them. Once approved, these blocks are added to the blockchain permanently. Validators ensure these blocks adhere to the consensus protocol, whether it‚Äôs Proof of Stake (PoS) or Delegated Proof of Stake (DPoS).
Maintaining Consensus: Validators participate in consensus mechanisms like Ethereum‚Äôs PoS, where they use staked tokens to confirm the blockchain‚Äôs current state. This process ensures all participants agree on the network‚Äôs data and prevents malicious activities like creating conflicting chains.
Ensuring Network Security: Validators act as the first line of defense against cyberattacks, such as 51% attacks or double-spending. Their diligence protects the blockchain from being compromised. For example, on networks like Solana, validators contribute to processing over 65,000 transactions per second, showcasing their critical role in network performance.

Being a validator also comes with incentives‚Äîvalidators earn rewards like transaction fees or newly minted tokens for their work. However, the role demands responsibility: validators in PoS systems risk losing their staked tokens if they act dishonestly, ensuring they always operate in the network‚Äôs best interest.

Ultimately, being a validator is not just about technical tasks ‚Äì it‚Äôs about ensuring the blockchain remains decentralized, transparent, and trustworthy for everyone.

Learn more: Top Web3 Security Tips to Keep Your Crypto Safe

Proof of Work vs. Proof of Stake (PoW vs. PoS)

Proof of Work (PoW) and Proof of Stake (PoS) are the two most popular consensus mechanisms in blockchain. Both play a crucial role in securing networks and maintaining operations, but they differ significantly in their approaches, energy consumption, and efficiency.

Proof of Work (PoW)

PoW is the original consensus mechanism, used by blockchains like Bitcoin.

How it works: Miners compete to solve complex mathematical problems using computational power. The first to solve the problem adds a new block to the blockchain. Rewards: Miners earn cryptocurrency and transaction fees for their efforts. Challenges: PoW is highly energy-intensive and requires expensive hardware, leading to high operational costs and significant environmental impact.

Example: According to Digiconomist, Bitcoin‚Äôs annual energy consumption is comparable to that of small countries like Argentina.

Proof of Stake (PoS)

PoS is a more modern and energy-efficient consensus mechanism, used by blockchains like Ethereum 2.0 and Cardano.

How it works: Validators ‚Äústake‚Äù a certain amount of cryptocurrency to gain the right to verify transactions and propose new blocks. Rewards: Validators earn rewards based on the amount they stake. Advantages: PoS is far more energy-efficient and scalable than PoW, making it more environmentally friendly and suitable for large-scale applications.

Example: After Ethereum transitioned from PoW to PoS (known as the Ethereum Merge), its energy consumption decreased by 99.95%, highlighting PoS‚Äôs sustainability.

Key Comparisons CriteriaProof of Work (PoW)Proof of Stake (PoS)Energy ConsumptionHighLowMechanismBased on computational powerBased on staked tokensScalabilityLimitedHighOperational CostsExpensiveAffordable

Both PoW and PoS have their strengths and weaknesses, serving different purposes. While PoW laid the foundation for blockchain technology, PoS is emerging as the preferred choice for its energy efficiency and scalability. The transition of Ethereum from PoW to PoS exemplifies the industry‚Äôs move toward more sustainable solutions for the future of blockchain.

Validators Vs. Miners: What‚Äôs the Difference?

In blockchain networks, validators and miners serve different purposes depending on the consensus mechanism used. Here‚Äôs a simple breakdown of their roles and differences:

Validators: The Backbone of Proof of Stake (PoS)

Validators are responsible for verifying transactions and approving blocks in Proof of Stake (PoS) systems. Instead of relying on computational power, they ‚Äústake‚Äù tokens as collateral to gain the right to validate transactions. Their tasks include:

Ensuring transactions follow network rules. Proposing and validating new blocks. Maintaining the blockchain‚Äôs consensus efficiently.

Validators are rewarded with transaction fees or newly minted tokens, but they risk losing their staked tokens if they act dishonestly. PoS mechanisms, used by networks like Ethereum 2.0 and Solana, are known for being energy-efficient and scalable.

Miners: The Workhorses of Proof of Work (PoW)

Miners, on the other hand, play a crucial role in Proof of Work (PoW) systems. They compete to solve complex mathematical puzzles using computational power, and the first to solve the puzzle gets to add a new block to the blockchain. Their rewards include:

Newly minted cryptocurrency (e.g., Bitcoin block rewards). Transaction fees for processing transactions.

However, mining is resource-intensive and requires significant energy, making it less sustainable than PoS systems. PoW mechanisms, like those used in Bitcoin, rely on high computational power to maintain security and decentralization.

Key Differences Energy Usage: Validators (PoS) use far less energy compared to miners (PoW). Mechanism: Validators stake tokens, while miners rely on solving puzzles. Efficiency: PoS systems are faster and more scalable, while PoW systems are more energy-intensive but highly secure. Insightful Example

The shift from PoW to PoS, as seen in Ethereum‚Äôs Merge update, highlights the growing preference for validator-based systems. Ethereum reduced its energy consumption by 99.95% after transitioning to PoS, showcasing how validators are a more sustainable alternative to miners.

In summary, both validators and miners are essential in blockchain networks but serve different functions based on the consensus mechanism. While miners laid the foundation for early blockchain systems like Bitcoin, validators are shaping the future of blockchain with efficient and eco-friendly systems like PoS.

How much can you get as a Validator?

The earnings of a validator in a blockchain network can vary significantly based on several factors, including the network, the number of tokens staked, and the reward mechanism. Here‚Äôs a simplified breakdown of how validator rewards work:

Types of Rewards

Validators earn rewards through two primary sources:

Newly Minted Tokens: Many blockchain networks, like Ethereum and Solana, distribute newly minted tokens to validators as an incentive. Transaction Fees: Validators also earn a share of the transaction fees collected from users on the network.

For example, Ethereum 2.0 validators can earn an average annual yield of 4-10%, depending on the total amount of ETH staked on the network.

Factors That Affect Rewards

The amount a validator earns is influenced by:

Staked Tokens: The more tokens you stake, the higher your chances of being selected to validate transactions and earn rewards. Network Inflation: Some blockchains have fixed inflation rates that determine the amount of newly minted tokens distributed. Performance: Consistently validating transactions accurately ensures maximum rewards, while downtime or mistakes can lead to penalties or slashed tokens. Competition: As the number of validators increases, the rewards are distributed among more participants, which can reduce individual earnings.

For instance, Cosmos validators earn an average annual reward of 7-20%, depending on network parameters and their staking pool size.

Potential Risks

While the rewards can be lucrative, becoming a validator comes with risks:

Token Volatility: Rewards are paid in cryptocurrency, so their value can fluctuate with market conditions. Slashing Penalties: Validators can lose a portion of their staked tokens for malicious activities or extended downtime. Conclusion

Validators are at the heart of blockchain innovation, particularly in the transition from Proof of Work (PoW) to Proof of Stake (PoS). By staking tokens, they maintain security, achieve consensus, and drive decentralization‚Äîall while earning rewards for their efforts. Whether you‚Äôre a blockchain enthusiast or a potential validator, understanding their role highlights the trustless, secure, and energy-efficient future of blockchain technology.

Learn more: Top Web3 Security Tips to Keep Your Crypto Safe

About Herond Browser

Herond Browser is a cutting-edge Web 3.0 browser designed to prioritize user privacy and security. By blocking intrusive ads, harmful trackers, and profiling cookies, Herond creates a safer and faster browsing experience while minimizing data consumption.

To enhance user control over their digital presence, Herond offers two essential tools:

Herond Shield: A robust adblocker and privacy protection suite. Herond Wallet: A secure, multi-chain, non-custodial social wallet.

As a pioneering Web 2.5 solution, Herond is paving the way for mass Web 3.0 adoption by providing a seamless transition for users while upholding the core principles of decentralization and user ownership.

Have any questions or suggestions? Contact us:

On Telegram https://t.me/herond_browser DM our official X @HerondBrowser Technical support topic on https://community.herond.org

The post What is a Validator? A Guide to Proof of Stake appeared first on Herond Blog.

08:11 • 19 days ago

Friday, 10. January 2025

KuppingerCole

Zero Data Loss: Peace of Mind in the Ransomware Era

by Alexei Balaganski Oh, how time flies! Can you believe that we‚Äôve been living with ransomware for over a decade already? Sure, a pedantic historian could explain that the first occurrences of malware encrypting files and asking for a ransom to restore access were recorded all the way back in 1989. Yet, it took another couple of decades for IT infrastructures and cryptocurrencies to evolve to a

by Alexei Balaganski

Oh, how time flies! Can you believe that we‚Äôve been living with ransomware for over a decade already? Sure, a pedantic historian could explain that the first occurrences of malware encrypting files and asking for a ransom to restore access were recorded all the way back in 1989. Yet, it took another couple of decades for IT infrastructures and cryptocurrencies to evolve to a stage when ransomware truly became profitable and turned into a major risk with global impact.

The public probably experienced it for the first time in 2013, when the CryptoLocker ransomware was able to infect over 250,000 systems and netted its creators over $3 million in ransom payments. By 2017, strains like WannaCry and NotPetya became notorious for causing billions in damage around the world, with the latter showing the true weaponization potential of ransomware. In fact, NotPetya‚Äôs creators were not even interested in collecting ransom, they just wanted to cause long-lasting damage to their victims.

And ever since, the entire world has been living under the constant fear of a ransomware attack. For many organizations, it has become the existential threat number one, surpassing all other known cybersecurity risks. It‚Äôs the combination of immediacy, unpredictability, and the severe consequences of even a single attack that makes it so scary, amplified even further by the lack of a single comprehensive solution to reliably prevent them in the future.

A proper strategy for ransomware prevention must include a broad range of measures, proactive and reactive, technology- and process-based, covering a multitude of attack vectors. These include everything from e-mail and web monitoring to endpoint detection and response to network security and identity governance. And yet, for most victims, the most viable scenario of surviving a ransomware attack is not to prevent it, but to contain the damage, restore their disrupted processes, and recover business-critical data as quickly and painlessly as possible‚Ä¶

With this realization, now is the right time to stop thinking about ransomware as malware that just encrypts or steals your files. In fact, it does much more direct and indirect damage than that ‚Äì and to start thinking of new tools to augment your existing anti-ransomware toolkit. This is especially relevant for backup and disaster recovery. For example, a lot has been written recently about immutable backups as a crucial factor for ransomware resilience. It is a well-known fact that modern ransomware specifically targets backup locations to make the recovery more difficult, but are you sure that you are even doing your backups properly in the first place?

Recently, I attended a presentation of Zero Data Loss Recovery Appliance, Oracle‚Äôs specialized solution for backing up mission-critical databases. While I was familiar with the product already, I was somewhat surprised that the company now positions it as a premier solution for ransomware protection. Wait, what? Do ransomware groups even consider relational databases a viable target? And isn‚Äôt Oracle‚Äôs own Autonomous Database with all its built-in security control supposed to be 100% resilient against these attacks anyway? However, the more I was thinking about it, the more sense it all started to make.

First, not even the most hardcore Oracle customers have all their data stored in the Autonomous Database, which is, after all, a managed cloud service. For many industries and applications, sensitive data has to stay on premises at all times. Second, even when the database itself is managed by a service provider, their responsibility does not extend to protecting the integrity of the customer‚Äôs data. And finally, ransomware attacks specifically targeting databases (relational and NoSQL) are not unheard of, especially when targeting specific high-profile victims! In the end, having a secure, reliable, and high-performant solution for backing up business-critical data from enterprise databases does make a lot of sense, since it can substantially speed up recovering from a ransomware attack.

Zero Data Loss Recovery Appliance (Recovery Appliance) is an engineered system for comprehensive data protection of Oracle databases, ensuring backup immutability, continuous validation, and rapid recovery without data loss, even in the event of a ransomware attack. It integrates natively with Oracle databases to consistently validate backup data, detect anomalies, and enforce retention policies, offering recovery up to the last sub-second before a data loss incident. The appliance supports flexible deployment architectures, including air-gapped Cyber Vaults, to enhance data protection and resilience. By consolidating incremental backups into space-efficient virtual full backups, Recovery Appliance minimizes recovery time while maintaining the highest data integrity and security standards.

Since the appliance is built on Oracle Exadata engineered system that customers leverage today for running the most critical enterprise Oracle databases, it inherits the underlying platform‚Äôs performance, scalability, and availability characteristics. And since it natively supports all the internal data structures and protocols of an Oracle Database, it offers unique capabilities that no third-party, especially file-based, backup tool can provide. It can operate in ‚Äúincremental forever‚Äù mode, only capturing small data changes in real time during backup but will reassemble (‚Äúmaterialize‚Äù) them into a consistent full copy on the fly when needed for restoration.

Of course, all the backup copies stored by the appliance are immutable, but in addition to that, they are continuously validated for recovery integrity, down to the transaction level. Whenever you need to restore data, you can have peace of mind knowing that it will be free from any tampering or anomalies, whether caused by ransomware or other data compromise, encryption, or corruption scenarios.

To boost the level of security and compliance even further, while still meeting the RTO/RPO requirements, it is possible to deploy the appliance in an ‚Äúair gap‚Äù configuration, further separating backup copies from production data. Whenever a full physical isolation is impossible or impractical, the combination of ZDLRA‚Äôs security features (immutable backups, end-to-end encryption, strict access controls, integrity checks) with network segmentation provides a strong level of ‚Äúlogical air-gapping‚Äù consistent with NIST best practices.

Recently, Oracle announced Zero Data Loss Autonomous Recovery Service, a cloud-native, Oracle managed counterpart of the on-premises appliance. It offers the same capabilities but in the cloud; in fact, the service is available in all clouds currently partnered with Oracle: Azure, GCP, and AWS. Cloud backups also have a significant advantage of being natively distributed across multiple availability zones, so they remain available even if a zone goes offline. It is even possible to quickly restore a backup to a different region or tenant to deal with catastrophic failures ‚Äì not just ransomware but natural disasters, like earthquakes or tornadoes.

The company is now working on integrating these two offerings to support hybrid deployments in the future. But even now, according to Oracle, the Recovery Service is projected to become their largest cloud service by total storage volume.

So, will it really protect your organization from ransomware attacks? I‚Äôm afraid that asking this kind of question is misleading and even somewhat dangerous. There is simply no single tool or technology that can provide complete protection, given the broad range of vulnerabilities and threat vectors that can be exploited by malicious actors. What it can offer though is a turn-key solution for a specific kind of risk ‚Äì a risk of losing access or compromising your critical sensitive data.

In a world where ransomware evolves faster than defenses, solutions like Oracle's Recovery Appliance are not just useful tools ‚Äì they‚Äôre lifelines, turning catastrophes into recoverable incidents and keeping your business resilient when it matters most.

If you‚Äôre looking for more information about Oracle's solution, check the links below:

Zero Data Loss Recovery Appliance Product Home
Zero Data Loss Autonomous Recovery Service Product Home
Oracle Backup & Recovery Technologies Blog Central
Oracle Backup & Recovery AskTOM Office Hours

Navigating KYC vs AML Compliance in Finance

KYC and AML are a set of best practices and processes to help businesses reduce their risk of fraud. Compliance is not optional for financial services, and the right infrastructure can ensure compliance and avoid costly fines. The post Navigating KYC vs AML Compliance in Finance first appeared on ComplyCube.

16:29 • 20 days ago

liminal (was OWI)

The State of Identity ‚Äì January 10, 2025

Liminal members enjoy the exclusive benefit of receiving daily morning briefs directly in their inboxes, ensuring they stay ahead of the curve with the latest industry developments for a significant competitive advantage. Looking for product or company-specific news? Log in or sign-up to Link for more detailed news and developments. Here are the main industry [‚Ä¶] The post The State of Identity ‚Äì

Liminal members enjoy the exclusive benefit of receiving daily morning briefs directly in their inboxes, ensuring they stay ahead of the curve with the latest industry developments for a significant competitive advantage.

Looking for product or company-specific news? Log in or sign-up to Link for more detailed news and developments.

Here are the main industry highlights of this week week impacting identity and fraud, cybersecurity, trust and safety, financial crimes compliance, and privacy and consent management.

ü™ÑInnovation and New Technology Developments

Texas Lottery Implements Mandatory ID Scans for Age Verification at Self-Serve Vending Machines

The Texas Lottery Commission has introduced mandatory age verification for purchasing lottery tickets from self-serve vending machines, requiring buyers to scan a government-issued photo ID. This measure, implemented using the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators verification system, ensures compliance with the 18-and-over age requirement. The Commission assures that no data is collected or stored during the process, emphasizing that it is solely for age verification. (Source)

India‚Äôs Draft Digital Personal Data Protection Rules, 2025: Age Verification, Parental Consent, and Data Oversight Under Scrutiny

India‚Äôs draft Digital Personal Data Protection Rules, 2025, by MeitY, require age assurance and parental consent for minors under 18 to access social media. Platforms must verify parental identity via government sources like DigiLocker but lack clarity on age verification methods, excluding tools like biometric facial estimation. The rules mandate data breach notifications, dormancy-based data deletion, and establish a Data Protection Board with penalties up to ‚Çπ2.5 billion (~$29.2M). Critics, including the Internet Freedom Foundation, cite transparency issues and limited regional language access. Public comments are invited until February 18, 2025. (Source)

Telegram Introduces Third-Party Verification, NFT Gifts, and Enhanced Search for Safer, Interactive Platform Experience

Telegram has launched a third-party account verification system, enabling verified organizations, such as food-quality regulators or educational consortiums, to authenticate accounts with unique logos instead of blue checkmarks. This decentralized model aims to combat scams and misinformation while raising safety standards on social platforms. Other updates include NFT-based gifts created with Telegram Stars, tradeable on external platforms, new message search filters for chats, groups, and channels, expanded cryptocurrency monetization options, and emoji reactions for service messages to boost user engagement. (Source)

Pakistan Introduces Biometric Registration for Children to Enhance Security and Digital Identity Systems

Pakistan has introduced biometric registration for children aged 10 to 18 as part of civil registry updates. Starting January 1, 2025, the Child Registration Certificate (CRC) will feature fingerprint biometrics and facial photos, enhancing passport applications and security. Initiated by Federal Interior Minister Mohsin Naqvi, the measure aims to curb fraud, combat human trafficking, and improve services via the Pak ID mobile app. Future plans include adding iris scans and linking NADRA‚Äôs database with Union Councils for a unified digital ID system. (Source)

India‚Äôs MOSIP Seeks Collaboration with SADC to Strengthen Digital Identity Systems Across Southern Africa

India‚Äôs Modular Open-Source Identity Platform (MOSIP) is working with the Southern African Development Community (Sadc) to enhance identification systems across its 16 member states. The platform enables governments to create scalable, customizable identity systems without vendor lock-in. MOSIP has collaborated with South Africa, is engaging Zambia, and is being considered by Nigeria for its digital identity system. Inspired by the EU‚Äôs Digital Identity Wallet, MOSIP prioritizes secure data transfer and user consent in its digital identity framework. (Source)

üí∞ Investments and Partnerships

TransUnion to Fully Acquire UK-Based Credit Platform Monevo, Boosting Consumer Credit Solutions

TransUnion has signed a definitive agreement to acquire the remaining ownership of Monevo, a UK-based credit prequalification and distribution platform, after initially acquiring a 30% stake in 2021. The transaction, expected to close by Q2 2025 pending regulatory approvals, will be funded with existing cash-on-hand and is not projected to materially impact TransUnion‚Äôs 2025 financial performance. The acquisition aims to enhance both companies‚Äô value propositions by offering optimised credit solutions at scale and expanding their direct-to-consumer strategy in the U.S. and UK. Monevo‚Äôs platform connects over 150 global lenders and publishers, allowing consumers to compare tailored credit offers, improving approval visibility and minimizing credit score impact from unnecessary searches. (Source)

1Password Acquires Trelica to Enhance SaaS Access Management and Strengthen Extended Access Platform

TransUnion has agreed to acquire full ownership of Monevo, a UK-based credit prequalification and distribution platform, after acquiring a 30% stake in 2021. The deal, expected to close by Q2 2025 pending regulatory approvals, will be funded with existing cash and is not anticipated to significantly affect TransUnion‚Äôs 2025 financial performance. The acquisition aims to scale optimized credit solutions and expand direct-to-consumer offerings in the U.S. and UK. Monevo‚Äôs platform connects over 150 global lenders and publishers, enabling consumers to compare tailored credit offers with improved approval transparency and reduced credit score impact from unnecessary searches. (Source)

ClearScore Acquires Aro Finance to Strengthen Embedded Finance and Secured Loan Offerings

ClearScore Group has acquired Aro Finance Ltd to expand into embedded finance and secured loan broking, leveraging partnerships with major UK retailers like Argos, Very.co.uk, and Asda. This acquisition combines Aro‚Äôs lending marketplace capabilities with ClearScore‚Äôs platform, enhancing borrowing options and integrating the Group‚Äôs debt consolidation tool, ‚ÄúClearer,‚Äù which directly settles consumer debts. Following its 2022 acquisition of Money Dashboard, ClearScore has bolstered its open banking expertise to improve underwriting and risk management. Pending FCA approval, Aro‚Äôs Manchester team will join ClearScore, advancing its strategy to diversify offerings and serve its 24 million global users. (Source)

‚öñÔ∏è Policy and Regulatory

EU General Court Fines European Commission for GDPR Breach in Landmark Ruling

The EU General Court has fined the European Commission ‚Ç¨400 ($412) for violating its own data protection laws, marking a precedent-setting decision. The Commission unlawfully transferred a German citizen‚Äôs personal data, including their IP address, to Meta Platforms in the U.S. without proper safeguards. The breach occurred when the citizen used the ‚ÄúSign in with Facebook‚Äù feature on the EU login webpage to register for a conference. This ruling underscores the EU‚Äôs commitment to enforcing GDPR compliance, which has previously resulted in fines for major companies like Meta and LinkedIn. (Source)

U.S. Defense Department Expands Chinese Military Companies List to Include Biometrics and Tech Giants

The U.S. Department of Defense has updated its Section 1260H list of Chinese military companies, adding firms like Cloudwalk, Dahua, Hikvision, Huawei, Tencent, Yitu, and SenseTime for their dual-use technologies supporting China‚Äôs military. While the listing has no immediate legal impact, it raises the risk of sanctions and has caused market disruptions, including stock declines. Some firms, such as Dahua and Hikvision, face allegations of involvement in Xinjiang human rights abuses, while others, like Tencent and SenseTime, deny military ties. Megvii was removed from the list, which China criticized as exaggerating the ‚ÄúChina threat‚Äù for national security purposes. (Source)

Rivers Casino Philadelphia Faces Lawsuits Over Major Data Breach Exposing Sensitive Employee and Customer Information

Rivers Casino Philadelphia, operated by Rush Street Gaming, faces legal scrutiny after a November 2024 data breach exposed sensitive employee and customer information, including Social Security numbers and bank details. Disclosed in December, the breach has prompted lawsuits, including a class-action complaint citing negligence and weak data security. Critics claim the casino‚Äôs response was delayed and inadequate, with victims reporting phishing and fraud. The incident underscores growing cybersecurity concerns in the gaming industry, a prime target for hackers due to its valuable data. (Source)

SEBI Fines Stockholding Services ‚Çπ9 Lakh for Systemic KYC Violations and Data Discrepancies

SEBI fined Stockholding Services Ltd ‚Çπ9 lakh for multiple KYC violations, including listing 1,103 clients aged 34-100 as ‚Äúdependent children.‚Äù Inspections uncovered issues like mismatched contact details, incorrect bank information, and the use of authorized persons‚Äô contact details instead of clients‚Äô. While the brokerage attributed errors to outdated practices and client confusion, it updated 947 accounts and suspended 156. SEBI stressed the systemic nature of the violations and the importance of robust KYC norms for transparency and preventing illegal activities. (Source)

Washington State Sues T-Mobile Over 2021 Data Breach That Exposed Millions‚Äô Personal Information Due to Alleged Cybersecurity Failures

Washington State has sued T-Mobile over a 2021 data breach that exposed sensitive information of over 79 million customers. The lawsuit alleges failure to address known cybersecurity weaknesses, inadequate customer notification, and misrepresentation of data protection measures. Exposed data included names, Social Security numbers, and driver‚Äôs license details, some of which surfaced on a cybercriminal forum. The suit cites technical flaws like weak credentials, no login rate-limiting, and poor monitoring. T-Mobile disputes the claims, calling the lawsuit unexpected and expressing willingness to engage in further discussions. (Source)

China-Linked Hackers Breach U.S. Treasury in Cyberattack, CISA Finds No Evidence of Wider Federal Intrusion

CISA reported no evidence of U.S. federal agencies being hacked beyond the Treasury Department in a December cyberattack. China-backed hackers accessed Treasury employee workstations and unclassified documents using a stolen private key from vendor BeyondTrust. The method of theft remains unclear, but the hackers targeted the global sanctions office. China denies involvement, while CISA continues monitoring and coordinating the response. (Source)

InfoCert Data Breach Exposes 5.5 Million Users‚Äô Personal Data Amid Third-Party Supplier Vulnerability

Italian digital identity provider InfoCert suffered a data breach affecting 5.5 million customers, with stolen data, including names, tax codes, and contact details, appearing on the dark web. The breach stemmed from a third-party supplier, not InfoCert‚Äôs systems, and no passwords or service credentials were compromised. InfoCert, part of the Tinexta Group and managing 1.8 million SPID identities, disclosed the incident before removing the notice and is investigating while reporting to authorities. The breach underscores cybersecurity challenges in the digital identity sector amid rising threats. (Source)

U.S. Sanctions Chinese Firm Integrity Tech Over Alleged Cyber Espionage Links to Flax Typhoon

The U.S. sanctioned Beijing-based Integrity Technology Group, linked to China-backed hacking group Flax Typhoon, for aiding cyberattacks on U.S. entities, including critical infrastructure, universities, and media. Between 2022 and 2023, Integrity Tech allegedly operated a botnet of 260,000 devices to hide Flax Typhoon‚Äôs activities, dismantled by the FBI in September 2024. The sanctions follow a December cyberattack on the Treasury Department‚Äôs OFAC, attributed to China-backed hackers, potentially exposing sensitive sanctions-related data. The U.S. has labeled Chinese cyber actors a persistent national security threat. Integrity Tech has not responded to the allegations. (Source)

Hong Kong Police Bust AI-Powered Deepfake Syndicate Behind $4.4 Billion Global ‚ÄòPig Butchering‚Äô Scams

Hong Kong authorities dismantled a syndicate using AI deepfakes and dating apps to defraud victims in Taiwan, Singapore, and Malaysia, stealing over HK$34 million. Operating from Kowloon Bay, 31 suspects were arrested, and HK$100 million in assets, including cash and luxury goods, was seized. The group used face-swapping technology to create fake personas, luring victims into romantic relationships and convincing them to invest in fraudulent cryptocurrency platforms. Victims were blocked from withdrawing funds under pretexts like taxes, a hallmark of ‚Äúpig butchering‚Äù scams. The operation, involving extensive money laundering, was led by the Commercial Crime Bureau. (Source)

Apple Settles $95 Million Lawsuit Over Siri Privacy Violations and Unintentional Recordings

Apple has agreed to a $95 million settlement to resolve a class-action lawsuit alleging Siri violated user privacy by unintentionally recording conversations and sharing them with third parties, including advertisers. Filed in October 2023 in Oakland, California, the settlement awaits approval from US District Judge Jeffrey White. The lawsuit claims Siri‚Äôs accidental activations led to targeted ads based on overheard discussions, covering a class period from September 2014 to December 2024, spanning the ‚ÄúHey, Siri‚Äù feature‚Äôs release. (Source)

U.S. Court Rules FCC Lacks Authority to Reinstate Net Neutrality, Shifting Focus to State Laws and Congress

A U.S. appeals court ruled that the FCC cannot reinstate net neutrality rules, citing the Supreme Court‚Äôs Loper Bright decision limiting federal agency powers. The decision blocks Biden administration efforts to restore open internet principles but leaves state-level rules, like California‚Äôs, intact. FCC Chair Jessica Rosenworcel called on Congress to legislate net neutrality, while industry leaders and former FCC Chair Ajit Pai praised the ruling, favoring investment over federal oversight. The decision may hinder federal internet regulation, though further legal action is possible. (Source)

15:00 • 20 days ago

Herond Browser

How Social Wallet Login Is Bridging the Gap Between Web2 and Web3

Social wallet login is transforming how we access digital platforms, making it easier and more convenient for users to navigate between Web2 and Web3. Instead of managing complicated private keys or passphrases, users can now log in using familiar accounts like Facebook, Google, or Apple ID. This simple yet powerful feature is bridging the gap [‚Ä¶] The post How Social Wallet Login Is Bridging the

Social wallet login is transforming how we access digital platforms, making it easier and more convenient for users to navigate between Web2 and Web3. Instead of managing complicated private keys or passphrases, users can now log in using familiar accounts like Facebook, Google, or Apple ID. This simple yet powerful feature is bridging the gap between traditional internet experiences and blockchain-based applications, paving the way for wider Web3 adoption. 

Learn more: What is a Seed Phrase and Why is it Important for Wallet Security?

What is social login?

Social Login is a quick and easy way for users to access websites or apps using their existing social media accounts, like Facebook, Google, or Twitter. Instead of creating new accounts or remembering extra passwords, users can log in with just one click. This not only saves time but also simplifies the user experience, making it easier for platforms to attract and retain users.

In the context of Web3, Social Wallet Login is still a new concept. Traditionally, Web3 users log in using wallet passphrases or private keys, which are long and complex. By integrating Social Login, crypto platforms can bridge the gap between Web2 and Web3, paving the way for broader adoption of blockchain technology.

4 popular forms of social wallet logins

Social wallet logins are becoming increasingly common as they simplify access to platforms. Here are four widely used types:

Facebook Login: With over 2.9 billion monthly users worldwide, Facebook Login is one of the most popular options. It allows users to sign in quickly using their Facebook accounts, making the process seamless and widely accessible. Google Login: Leveraging Google‚Äôs vast ecosystem, this method enables users to log in securely and effortlessly with their Google accounts. It‚Äôs a convenient option for platforms aiming to tap into Google‚Äôs trusted services and user base. Apple ID Login: Tailored for Apple users, this method offers a simple and fast login experience. However, it‚Äôs mainly suitable for users within Apple‚Äôs ecosystem, like iPhone or MacBook owners. LinkedIn Login: Often used in professional settings, LinkedIn Login is perfect for platforms requiring professional profiles or credentials. It‚Äôs ideal for job portals, networking sites, and other career-focused applications.

Each form of social wallet login offers unique benefits, helping users connect to platforms effortlessly while enhancing overall user experience.

Learn more: What is Crypto Wallet and How to Use Them Safely

The importance of integrating Social Wallet Login into Crypto Web3 Wallets

Integrating Social Wallet Login into Web3 wallets is a game-changer, especially in the crypto world where user adoption still faces hurdles. Here‚Äôs why it‚Äôs important:

Simplifying User Experience: Traditional Web3 wallets require users to manage complex private keys or passphrases, which can be intimidating. Social Wallet Login simplifies this by allowing users to log in with familiar social media accounts, making the process faster and less overwhelming. Recovering Access Made Easy: Losing private keys can lead to losing access to crypto assets permanently. Social Login ties wallets to recoverable social accounts, ensuring users can regain access if they forget their credentials. Encouraging Adoption: By offering a seamless and familiar login process, Social Wallet Login lowers the barrier to entry for new users, encouraging broader adoption of crypto wallets and decentralized apps (dApps). Enhanced Identity Verification (KYC): Social media accounts often have built-in identity verification. Integrating these into Web3 wallets can streamline KYC processes, especially for decentralized finance (DeFi) platforms that require compliance.

This integration not only boosts convenience but also paves the way for mass adoption of Web3 by bridging the gap between traditional users and the complexities of blockchain technology.

Learn more: Multi-Chain Wallets: Manage Different Blockchains in One Place

Herond Wallet ‚Äì Trusted and easy social wallet login for beginners

Whether you‚Äôre new to crypto or a seasoned user, Herond Wallet offers an easy, secure, and versatile solution to explore decentralized apps and manage digital assets. It‚Äôs the future of Web3‚Äîsimple, secure, and accessible for all. Below are 4 reasons that build the reputation and trustworthiness of this social login wallet:

Simplified Login for Everyone

Tired of remembering long passwords and managing seed phrases? Herond Wallet makes it easy to log in using your email, Google, or social media accounts. With just one click, you‚Äôre ready to access the world of Web3.

Multi-Chain Compatibility

Herond Wallet supports top blockchains like Ethereum, Polygon, BNB Smart Chain, Solana, and more. You can manage coins, tokens, and NFTs all in one place, and even add custom blockchains in less than 30 seconds.

Your Security, Your Control

With its non-custodial design, Herond Wallet ensures your private keys always belong to you. Thanks to Multi-Party Computation (MPC) technology, your keys are split and stored across different locations, drastically reducing the risk of hacks.

A Keyless Future

Say goodbye to the hassle of seed phrases and private keys! Herond Wallet syncs seamlessly with your Herond Account, giving you access to your wallet on any device, anytime, anywhere.

Conclusion

Social wallet login is more than a convenience ‚Äì it‚Äôs a vital step toward making Web3 accessible to everyone. By integrating social logins into Web3 wallets, platforms can enhance user experience, boost security, and encourage adoption across a broader audience. Whether you‚Äôre managing NFTs or exploring decentralized apps, solutions like Herond Wallet ensure that Web3 is not just for experts but for everyone.

Metaverse Real Estate: Investing in the Virtual World

Metaverse real estate is here and changing the game. Imagine owning virtual land where you can create anything like stores, offices, or even theme parks ‚Äì in a limitless digital world. Secured as NFTs on the blockchain, these properties are transparent, secure, and full of potential. Whether you‚Äôre an investor or just exploring, let‚Äôs dive [‚Ä¶] The post Metaverse Real Estate: Investing in the Vir

Metaverse real estate is here and changing the game. Imagine owning virtual land where you can create anything like stores, offices, or even theme parks ‚Äì in a limitless digital world. Secured as NFTs on the blockchain, these properties are transparent, secure, and full of potential. Whether you‚Äôre an investor or just exploring, let‚Äôs dive into how metaverse real estate is shaping the future.

Learn more: Everything You Need to Know About Non-Fungible Tokens (NFTs)

What is Virtual Real Estate?

Virtual real estate is exactly what it sounds like ‚Äì digital land and properties that exist in the metaverse, a growing network of 3D virtual spaces. Think of it as the online version of real-world real estate, where you can buy, sell, lease, or even build on digital plots of land. These properties can host anything from virtual events and storefronts to galleries, offices, or even homes, creating spaces where people can connect and interact.

What makes virtual real estate unique is that it‚Äôs secured on the blockchain, with ownership recorded as NFTs (Non-Fungible Tokens). This means every transaction is transparent, secure, and impossible to tamper with. Just like in the physical world, the value of these properties depends on location, utility, and how much engagement they attract. For example, virtual plots in high-traffic areas of the metaverse are like owning prime real estate on a busy city street.

As more people and businesses embrace the metaverse, virtual real estate is becoming a new frontier for investment and creativity. It‚Äôs not just about owning digital land ‚Äì it‚Äôs about reimagining how we use space in a virtual world, with the only limit being your imagination.

Learn more: The rise of NFT art: How digital art is transforming the art world

5 differences between Metaverse Real Estate and Traditional Real Estate

Metaverse real estate is reshaping how we think about property ownership. Unlike physical land, virtual properties exist entirely in a digital world, offering new opportunities and challenges. Here‚Äôs a closer look at how metaverse real estate differs from traditional real estate.

Digital vs. Physical Space

Traditional real estate is tangible‚Äîit‚Äôs land, buildings, and spaces you can physically see and touch. Metaverse real estate, on the other hand, exists in a virtual environment. These digital plots of land are represented as NFTs (Non-Fungible Tokens) on the blockchain, giving them a unique identity and ownership record. While you can‚Äôt step on virtual land, it can host everything from virtual concerts to digital storefronts.

Unlimited Creativity

Physical properties are often bound by zoning laws, structural limitations, and geographic constraints. In the metaverse, your imagination sets the boundaries. A small virtual plot can become a sprawling digital park or a towering skyscraper. There are no construction permits to worry about‚Äîjust the platform‚Äôs technological capabilities and your vision.

How Value Is Determined

The value of physical real estate depends on factors like location, infrastructure, and nearby amenities. In the metaverse, value is driven by virtual foot traffic, proximity to popular digital spaces, and platform demand. A virtual plot next to a well-known NFT gallery or popular digital event venue can be worth significantly more than a less trafficked location.

Buying and Selling

Traditional real estate transactions involve lawyers, agents, and mountains of paperwork. In the metaverse, buying or selling property is fast, secure, and transparent. Transactions are handled on the blockchain, often using cryptocurrencies, and ownership is represented by NFTs. There‚Äôs no need for middlemen, making the process quick and hassle-free.

Maintenance and Upkeep

Owning physical property comes with ongoing responsibilities like repairs, renovations, and property taxes. Virtual real estate, however, requires digital upkeep, such as updating software, securing against hacks, or improving user experience. It‚Äôs generally less costly and time-consuming compared to maintaining a physical property.

Learn more: NFTs for Gamers: A Game-Changer

The future of Metaverse real estate: is it the next big investment?

Mark Zuckerberg, one of the most prominent advocates for the metaverse, stated in 2022: 

‚ÄúThe metaverse will not be built by one company. It will be built by creators and developers making new experiences and digital items that are interoperable and unlock a massively larger creative economy than anything we see today.‚Äù

This highlights the potential of metaverse real estate as a collaborative ecosystem where virtual spaces will serve as hubs for interaction, commerce, and innovation.

Unlike physical real estate, virtual properties are free from geographic constraints, offering unique ways to host events, build experiences, and engage audiences. However, the technology is still evolving, with challenges like simplifying property transactions and improving user interfaces. Despite these hurdles, the growing interest in web3 and the metaverse indicates strong potential for future growth.

For investors, metaverse real estate offers both opportunities and risks. While early adopters have seen impressive returns, the market remains speculative and heavily reliant on technological advancements. Whether it becomes the ‚Äúnext big thing‚Äù or stays niche will depend on how quickly society embraces this digital frontier.

What was the biggest metaverse real estate purchase to date?

The largest metaverse real estate transaction to date took place in May 2022, when Curzio Research acquired 19 commercial properties in TCG World for a staggering $5 million. This record-breaking purchase eclipsed previous high-profile deals, such as Republic Realm‚Äôs $4.3 million investment in The Sandbox in November 2021. These monumental transactions underscore the surging interest and value in virtual real estate, as the metaverse increasingly becomes a viable frontier for business and investment opportunities.

Notable Success Stories in Metaverse Real Estate

Beyond these headline-grabbing transactions, several projects have demonstrated the practical utility and profitability of virtual real estate, showcasing the diversity and possibilities within the metaverse:

Decentraland‚Äôs Genesis Plaza: A Gateway to the Metaverse

Located at the center of Decentraland, Genesis Plaza is more than just a landmark‚Äîit‚Äôs a community hub. With interactive exhibits and art installations, this space serves as a welcoming zone for newcomers to the platform. It highlights the potential of creating virtual communal areas that foster engagement, creativity, and exploration in the metaverse.

CryptoVoxels‚Äô Neon District: A Commercial Hotspot

The Neon District in CryptoVoxels is a vibrant, bustling zone filled with galleries, shops, and entertainment hubs. Known for its unique blend of blockchain technology and virtual reality, it attracts significant digital foot traffic, making it one of the most sought-after locations for virtual properties. It‚Äôs a testament to how commercial zones can thrive in virtual spaces by offering immersive experiences.

The Sandbox‚Äôs Atari Theme Park: Where Gaming Meets Real Estate

A collaboration between The Sandbox and the legendary gaming brand Atari, this virtual theme park redefines entertainment in the metaverse. With virtual roller coasters, arcade zones, and other attractions, it highlights the lucrative potential of partnerships between traditional brands and virtual platforms, drawing both investors and users alike.

Program-Ace‚Äôs MetaOffice: Redefining Corporate Collaboration

MetaOffice, developed by Program-Ace, brings a revolutionary approach to corporate workspaces in the metaverse. Designed for both PC and VR users, it supports presentations, collaborations, and even casual relaxation in immersive environments. With advanced features like full-body tracking, facial animations, and the capacity to host up to 32 participants per server, MetaOffice showcases how virtual real estate can transform professional interactions, making them more dynamic and engaging.

Conclusion

Metaverse real estate isn‚Äôt just a trend ‚Äì it‚Äôs a digital revolution. While risks exist, the opportunities for creativity, profit, and innovation are endless. As the metaverse grows, owning virtual property could become as valuable as physical land. Ready to explore this new frontier?

09:06 • 20 days ago

A Beginner‚Äôs Guide to Yield Farming in DeFi

Yield farming, often called ‚Äúliquidity mining,‚Äù is a DeFi strategy that lets you earn rewards by putting your crypto assets to work. By providing liquidity to platforms like Uniswap or Curve Finance, you can earn passive income in the form of interest, fees, or tokens. This guide breaks down how yield farming works, the best [‚Ä¶] The post A Beginner‚Äôs Guide to Yield Farming in DeFi appeared first

Yield farming, often called ‚Äúliquidity mining,‚Äù is a DeFi strategy that lets you earn rewards by putting your crypto assets to work. By providing liquidity to platforms like Uniswap or Curve Finance, you can earn passive income in the form of interest, fees, or tokens. This guide breaks down how yield farming works, the best platforms to use, and the risks you should watch out for before getting started.

Learn more: Ethereum Staking: What This Means & How to Stake ETH

What Is Yield Farming?

Yield farming, often referred to as ‚Äúliquidity mining,‚Äù is a strategy within the world of Decentralized Finance (DeFi) that enables users to maximize returns on their cryptocurrency holdings. By supplying liquidity to DeFi protocols, participants can earn rewards, typically in the form of governance tokens specific to that platform.

In simple terms, yield farming can be compared to ‚Äúfarming‚Äù with crypto assets. Users ‚Äúplant‚Äù their cryptocurrencies into DeFi platforms such as decentralized exchanges (DEXs), lending protocols, or staking pools to ‚Äúharvest‚Äù rewards. These rewards might include interest, transaction fees, or newly minted tokens.

The role of Yield farming in DeFi ecosystem

Beyond being a way to generate passive income, yield farming plays a crucial role in fostering the growth and sustainability of the DeFi ecosystem. Platforms rely on liquidity providers (LPs) to keep the system operational, ensuring there is sufficient liquidity for borrowing, lending, and trading activities. For users, this offers an opportunity to not only earn but also actively support decentralized financial innovation.

Interesting to note is how yield farming rewards have transformed over time. Initially, governance tokens like COMP (from Compound) or CRV (from Curve Finance) dominated the rewards landscape. Today, some platforms experiment with hybrid incentives, including stablecoins, cross-chain rewards, or even NFT collectibles, further diversifying yield farming‚Äôs appeal and applicability.

Learn more: What Are Dapps and Why Are They Important in Web3?

How Does Yield Farming Work?

Yield farming operates on the foundation of the Automated Market Maker (AMM) model, where Liquidity Providers (LPs) play a central role. LPs provide liquidity by depositing their cryptocurrency assets into liquidity pools‚Äîsmart contracts that hold funds to facilitate decentralized financial activities such as lending, borrowing, and token trading.

The Basic Process: Providing Liquidity to a Pool:
Users deposit their crypto assets (e.g., ETH or USDT) into liquidity pools. In return, they receive a share of the transaction fees generated within the pool, such as those from token swaps or lending activities. Earning Rewards:
Beyond transaction fees, many protocols incentivize liquidity provision by distributing additional rewards, often in the form of governance tokens or newly issued platform tokens (a process known as Liquidity Mining). These rewards encourage LPs to continuously supply liquidity, thereby supporting the platform‚Äôs growth. Smart Contract Coordination:
Smart contracts manage the entire process, including locking LPs‚Äô assets, calculating their share of rewards, and automating transactions within the pool. These contracts ensure transparency, security, and efficiency. Which Platforms Are Best for Yield Farming?

Choosing the best yield farming platform depends on individual goals and investment strategies. Below are some of the most prominent platforms, known for their stability, attractive yields, and advanced features:

Uniswap

Uniswap, one of the most popular platforms in DeFi, is renowned for its Automated Market Maker (AMM) model. Users supply liquidity to pools and earn rewards through transaction fees. It‚Äôs an ideal choice for those seeking a transparent, user-friendly, and straightforward solution.

Curve Finance

Focused on stablecoins, Curve Finance minimizes price volatility risks. Liquidity providers earn interest, transaction fees, and CRV tokens as rewards. This platform is perfect for investors favoring stability and long-term returns.

Compound

Compound offers competitive interest rates for lending and borrowing crypto assets. Liquidity providers earn dual rewards: interest from loans and COMP tokens, creating a lucrative dual-income stream.

Aave

Aave stands out for its flash loans and flexible lending protocols. The platform also features rate switching, allowing users to toggle between fixed and variable interest rates, providing greater control over asset management.

Beefy Finance

As a yield optimizer, Beefy Finance aggregates over 600 vaults to maximize APY (Annual Percentage Yield) automatically. Its automated harvesting process minimizes gas fees, making it an efficient option for yield maximization.

yEarn Finance

yEarn Finance optimizes profits by automatically reallocating assets to the most profitable protocols. This hands-free approach is perfect for users who want high returns without actively monitoring the market.

Synthetix

Synthetix enables users to mint synthetic assets like sUSD and use them to provide liquidity on other platforms. This allows for multi-source income optimization across various protocols.

Radix

A rising blockchain platform, Radix offers yield farming opportunities with APR rates up to 50%. However, users should note that some Radix protocols require KYC (Know Your Customer) verification for bridging, making it more restrictive than other platforms.

5 Risks to Watch Out for in Yield Farming

Yield farming offers an enticing opportunity to maximize profits from crypto assets, but it also comes with significant risks. Here are the top 5 risks users should consider before diving in:

Smart Contract Vulnerabilities

Yield farming heavily relies on smart contracts, which are not always thoroughly audited. Projects developed by smaller teams with limited budgets are particularly prone to bugs and security breaches. Even audited protocols like Curve Finance and Bzrx have faced exploitation, highlighting the importance of understanding contract risks.

Impermanent Loss

Impermanent loss occurs when token prices in a liquidity pool fluctuate significantly, reducing the total value of assets compared to simply holding them. This risk is common in platforms like Uniswap and Balancer, especially during periods of high market volatility.

Price Volatility and Liquidation Risks

DeFi assets used as collateral can be liquidated if their value drops sharply due to market volatility. Users must closely monitor collateral ratios to avoid losing their positions.

Rug Pull Scams

Rug pulls involve project developers launching a token, attracting liquidity from users, and then selling off their holdings, draining the pool‚Äôs funds and rendering the token worthless. This is a major risk with unverified or low-reputation projects.

Liquidity Depletion

Liquidity in pools can vanish quickly if many users withdraw their assets simultaneously. This creates high slippage, where users receive less than expected when exchanging tokens. Additionally, locking tokens in pools reduces flexibility to respond to market changes.

Conclusion

Yield farming offers an exciting way to grow your crypto assets while supporting the DeFi ecosystem. By understanding the risks and choosing the right platforms, you can make the most of this innovative investment strategy. As always, careful research and risk management are key.

Learn more: Top Web3 Security Tips to Keep Your Crypto Safe

Herond Shield: A robust adblocker and privacy protection suite. Herond Wallet: A secure, multi-chain, non-custodial social wallet.
